description.narrative:
CEFORD is a local actor based in WwestNile with Headquaters in ARUA implementing the ELNHA coordination role and humanitarian capacity fund with -The goal to save lives, reduce suffering and protect human dignity for female as well as male refugees and host community members in West Nile sub-region of Uganda. CEFORD will provide humanitarian leadership in West Nile region (sub regions) and encourage local partners to work collectively, towards complementarity, coherence and harmonization of service delivery; convene and facilitate regular coordination meetings among the humanitarian actors and ensure that they are well-managed, action and results-oriented. # Capacity development: Identifying the local humanitarian actors in Arua, Koboko and Yumbe districts from Government, Civil Society <(>&<)> Private sector for collaboration as well as supporting those actors in theircapacity building effort based on identified needs. # Design and implement interventions: With guidance from Oxfam, lead the design of capacity building plans with local actors and support operationalization of the Humanitarian contingency plans in liaison with the District and other humanitarian actors. # Policy influencing: Work with existing platforms to lobby and advocate for improved service delivery, pro-active actors in humanitarian service delivery. # Learning, Reporting and documentation: Ensuring effective information sharing among local actors and with OXFAM. Disseminate relevant materials, reports, documentations, meeting minutes etc. Ensure all the partners are informed about field level and regional level coordination meetings and events;support peer to peer learning among the local actors in Arua and Koboko using existing structures, networks and other platforms.
By the project design Oxfam working along with the Lead Partners like CEFORD will strengthen the capacity of local and national humanitarian actors, so that they can lead humanitarian action in Uganda. We will work to give them the voice to create a strong domestic humanitarian agenda, by giving them the opportunity to design and implement quality humanitarian programs. The program createS the space by influencing other international NGOs and donors to contributeto this systemic change. The expectation at the end of the project to see; Capable Local and National Humanitarian Actors (LNHA) inUganda play a leading role in humanitarian work, putting the interest of women, men and children affected by disaster at the center.
The project would like to be part ofthis campaign agenda to shift humanitarian assistance usually led by UN agencies and international NGOs to domestic actors which are usually perceived to lack, the skills, systems and financial resources needed to carry out effective response. Project Goal: To contribute to strengthening the capacity of District Local Governments and LocalNon-GovernmentalActors to respond to humanitarian action in Arua,Koboko and Arua Districts of WestNile. Project aims to realise the following: # Improved humanitarian planning and response of District Local Governments and Local Non-Governmental Actors to lead a strong domestic humanitarian agenda. # Increased access to information on humanitarian emergencies.
# Enhanced capacity of local actors to influence thecentral government, international NGOs and donors to endorse and fund local actors#humanitarian action initiatives
A total of 21 Local actors are targeted in the 3 districts of Arua,Yumbe and Koboko in WestNile region.

participating-org.narrative: COMMUNITY EMPOWERMENT FOR RURAL DEV CEFORD

The history of Community Empowerment for Rural Development (CEFORD) dates back to 1993 when the Uganda government, with the financial and technical support of the Dutch government, implemented the Community Action Program (CAP) and later the Women Empowerment Program (WEP) in the West Nile region. Both programs were considered successes by the communities and district local governments of West Nile, and external evaluators and the Dutch embassy in Uganda. The focus was on community mobilisation and capacity building through service delivery and the implementation of micro-projects. CAP concentrated on the supply of social infrastructure services and the implementation of agricultural projects, while WEP concentrated on the empowerment of women and the strengthening of their capacities to participate in the development process. Thus CEFORD was founded, to fill the gap created by the closure of these successful programs that were phased out in June 2000. CEFORD operates in parts of all the five districts of Adjumani, Arua, Moyo, Nebbi and Yumbe. It was founded in July 2000 but the process of its formation dates back to 1998, to an internal reflection workshop of CAP staff that identified possible scenarios for the future. One scenario suggested a merger of CAP and WEP into a local NGO. The decentralisation of government to districts in Uganda also demanded strong civil society organisations that could support local governments indelivering services. CEFORD's major achievements in the last three years include a participatory poverty assessment in the districts of Arua and Nebbi. Through these assessments CEFORD gave objective feedback from poor women and men to the district and central governments, and to some donor. It was also successful in supporting the Adjumani district local government in facilitating the formulation of all its sub-county development plans. This enhanced its chance of accessing funds from the central government, from which the communities would benefit. And CEFORD strengthened the capacities of four local organisations through organisational self-assessment and the facilitation of strategic planning. The performance of these organisations has since improved. It also mobilised and linked ten community-based organisations to funding for agricultural activities; over 30 million Ugandan shillings from the German Development Services. CEFORD's Mission is to improve the capacity of women, men, children and their organisations in the more disadvantaged communities of West Nile effectively to articulate their demands and interests, to increase their production and income in a sustainable way and to secure better access to services. The institutional objectives of CEFORD are to contribute to the following policy and practice changes in West Nile: food and income security is guaranteed, communities have positive attitude to the enrolment and retention of girls in schools, there is active participation of the population in district and sub-county planning and policy formulation (especially around issues of natural resources, peace and security), peace and security in the region are consolidated especially at the household level, and women are empowered to participate as equal partners to men in decision-making and control over resources at the household and community levels.
